column11: Review Text
Good place for surfing anyone. Good beach. Lot of foreigners and highly Recommended this area and good beach. Come and enjoy anyone

KIRA SURF SCHOOL & BEACHBAR Tucked away in the shadow under Takama trees. West corner of Hiriketiya Beach. We loved it. Surflessons 1-1 our group Surf Tours to other beaches Jungle and Yoga camp Best Music Friendly Atmosphere Cool ‚ù§Ô∏è
I amazed how this beach looks nice and clean which is not overly crowded. It has nice waves and nice place to surf. Also there are ample restaurants available along side the beach road.

Small beach with focus on surf, lots of surfers in the water waiting for the perfect wave. If you want to take a surf course it is perfect, available along the entire beach. High pulse and beach joint throughout the beach. No suitable beach for children or you who want peace and quiet. Go over the hill to Dikwella beach where you will find a wonderful shallow beach with several cozy beach joints
Hiriketiya popular for surfing good waves and nice beach ..they have  good restaurants and hotels surf for best  at hiriketiya .
I didn't like it at all. There is no real beach, the restaurants cover all the beach...many people and garbage. Run away after one night

Nice little bay. With swell for surfing üèÑ. The beach is lined from front to back with bars and loungers. Rent a surfboard every 30 meters. Small shops all very lively. Who likes it that way. OK. Nature, however, clearly suffers and man suffers. Quiet is somewhere else.

Shallow  sandy beach  with beautiful bay as small and popular it is often crowded. People who love festive feeling can enjoy a lot there are so many hotels and resorts to get your food and beverage as well as accommodation

The most happening beach in Sri Lanka, this spot offers a perfect blend of serenity and vibrant atmosphere. With its stunning views and tranquil ambiance, it's an ideal destination for relaxation. The beach is lined with top-notch restaurants that provide delectable meals with a picturesque ocean backdrop. Whether you're looking to unwind with a peaceful stroll or savor a delicious meal with the sound of waves in the background, this beach delivers on all fronts. It's a must-visit for anyone wanting to experience the best of Sri Lanka's coastal charm.
Hiriketiya is a quaint little beach town with plenty of sun, surf and food. The bay and the beach is beautiful. Dont forget to visit the second largest blow hole, turtle hatchery and the silent beach

You're five years too late. This place used to be great: the surf is phenomenal for beginners/ intermediates and the beach is stunning. My family was here in 2019 and it was wonderful. It's now awful; full of private stone & glass villas called things like 'M@NG' and 'Sponge' that are full of people with daddy's Centurion card pretending they're roughing it. Don't go in the sea if the lagoon has burst, either, or you'll get sick.

Went there on a recommendation only to find it full of hippies, Ibiza types and surfers. The beach was nice enough but more geared up for the younger generation. The beach was in an enclave and the sea was a surfers paradise. Plenty of places to get a drink and food - as there were expensive types with pool overlooking the beach to the shack style places.

One of the more popular beaches for tourists along the SL coastline. The beach is not all that long and is lined all along wirh beach vendors selling food, drink & sunbeds (free if you buy something). With all the sunbeds it doesn't leave much open sand to enjoy. Very safe for swimming though you do have to keep an eye on the beginner surfers taking advantage of the smaller waves in the centre of the beach. Experienced surfers head out to the eastern pount where the waves are bigger. Food & drinks are not cheap but that's the trade off for a slice of paradise.

Excellent clean and charming beach, whether for relaxing on a deckchair and reading, swimming (in the middle) or surfing (amateurs in the middle, experienced on both sides). We went there several times and had a great time.
Beautiful beach, great beach facilities, water temperature (29.6 degrees). Be aware that the sea is rough and has strong currents (for those who like calm seas).
Very high music volume, children shouting at the bar pool. It looks like one of our beaches in August, you can only glimpse and imagine the beauty of this beach. You can surf. European prices

Totally overrated. We had booked a week at the Palm House Hiriketiya. 2 weeks before check-in we were asked to cancel our booking via Booking.com. It was not possible due to renovations. When we got there we saw that another guest was staying there. He had probably paid the better price over New Year. That was just the first rip-off. We booked another hotel. When we arrived there was no water. The whole place was affected, which of course was not true. Later in a seafood restaurant we ordered red snapper. But it wasn't red snapper and was totally inedible. We still had to pay $30 for fish with 2 beers. And so it went on. The only good thing was smoke and bitters. The beach was crowded and there was a children's playground.
Excellent and very beautiful beach with golden sand. Surfers love it but the vibe on the beach is great. Shallow clean waters.

Hiriketiya Beach is one of the places we had heard least about when we were planning our 3 week trip around Sri Lanka. I wouldn‚Äôt quite call it the hidden gem of the south coast, as it is growing in popularity, but it‚Äôs not too far off it. The neighboring town, Dikwella (known locally as Dickwella), has become a huge draw to people visiting Sri Lanka‚Äôs south coast. The laid-back lifestyle and surf vibes at Hiriketiya Beach and Dikwella have created those amazing coastal towns we absolutely love. The result is this magnetic draw similar to other trendy surf towns worldwide, whether it is Siargao in the Philippines, Tofino in Canada or Margaret River in Australia ‚Äì people love the environment it creates. The fun atmosphere and dreamy setting make it an incredible place to spend a few days. There are loads of awesome things to do, cheap places to eat and endless waves to surf.
Excellent destination, nice beach, to do with the family, pleasant restaurant, easy access. We spent three very pleasant days.
Perfect beach. Great stop while en route to Yala. Very touristy. Wished there were bbq facilities would've just made this a complete package.

True blue hidden Gem. We stopped here for an hour enroute to Yala. Ended up spending 3. We had lunch at La Playa. Great place, on the beach , swimming pool , lounge seats and et all. Beach has a gradual coastline and grea for surfing room
Beautiful beach. Make sure you don't turn up on a rainy day. Quite touristy and felt quite safe as well.
A really beautiful beach. Great for families as well as party goers, with an active night life. Great surfing beach. Lots of good restaurants and hotels without breaking ur wallet.

Great beach to o with your family. The ocean is safe, and you can get some simple eats, drinks and beach chairs on the beach under the shade of a palm umbrella. Truly an amazing beach. My granddaughter, 4 years old, just loved it.
Very nice place. Yo see the very vast ocean and clear we can play a lots enjoyed. The beach has many other activities to be done in the water and many more restaurant.

Beautiful beach. Quiet in August. Good local bars ranging from Dots to Smoke &Bitters. Lots of surfing opportunities, and some friendly locals to help you have an amazing time. Here with a family of 5. Very safe and enough to see and do for us all.
Wonderful experience with surfing and relaxing and enjoying on the beach beautiful bay and lots of restaurants around

This is the most beautiful beach I have been to. Paradise sandy cove, swimming, surfing, lovely relaxed but high quality  local cafes and restaurants with lush gardens, monkeys and colourful birds. Unspoilt by commercialisation, no big hotels or busy roads nearby.

Absolutely loved this beach, the vibe, and the views. If you want to chill, swim, snorkeling or surf - this place is the right one. Away from crowds with a few places to eat, drink and get a sunbed. You can rent surfboards (very cheap) in here . There are 2 surfing areas: the main beach break (perfect for beginners) and a fast left wave in the Eastern side of the beach.  I was surfing when green turtles popped up right under me! That was so unique. The vibe in the water is also incredible - people surfing here are very cheering and happy. No screaming or unnecessary competition for waves. It's just perfect. So far my favorite beach in Sri Lanka ! The western side of the beach is very calm and no waves if you want to swim and snorkel. Upon consuming something at the beach bar you can use the sunbeds without any extra charge (opposite to most places in Unawatuna, Dalawella or Mirissa).

Between 10am and 5pm you can walk from one end of this beach to the other across the loungers and then back again over the surf on top of the boards without getting any sand or sea in-between your toes. Despite this it‚Äôs a beautiful bay that we had more or less to ourselves at sunrise every morning. You can also find a nice spot under a tree to read your book away from the bars that play non-stop reggae. Businesses have grown organically along the beach and it‚Äôs just a matter of time before more established hotels take over. C‚Äôest La Vie! There are some great places to eat and sleep near Hiri beach. If you‚Äôre looking for a quiet, chilled-out, deserted spot then head to Dikwella beach and the guys at Machan‚Äôs hut will sort you out with a magical g&t.

One of the best beaches in Srilanka, amazing spot for beginner Surfers, my fianc√©e and I took the Surfing course with one of the best instructors in Hiriketiya his Facebook page is Sachith Dahanayake he is very patient and talented, he made us stand after two pushes, we really enjoyed it, now we can stand on the board and most importantly we had so much funüòä
Sri lanka wonderful and surfing üèÑ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è beach in down south DICKWELLA  hiriketiya now open enjoy now. Booking available hotel  room and  food  restaurant now open.
A very beautiful beach. Great for sunrise, surfing and a bit of swimming. Nice restaurants along the beach. The beach itself is very narrow so can get quite crowded.

Hiriketiya really is a lovely little beach and my friends and I had a nice 3 days of relaxation here at the end of our 3 week trip, but I did not love it. It is quite a small beach and most of it is taken up by surf board rentals, restaurant/cafe tables and sun loungers for rent, leaving almost no sand free. You really do need to rent sun loungers as there is little space to spread out your towels on the sand and if you have children there isn't much room for them to play.  It may be a good spot to learn to surf, but if that is not your aim there may be better options.

We first visited 2 years ago and it was lovely only a couple of eating places and food was great, now a never ending supply of restaurants and food crap, there is a never ending supply of oh to cool for school European wanky hipsters who following the below rules 1.  Make sure you get all your tattooes before you go. 2. Men make sure you have your man bun 3.  Ladies make sure you have the smallest bikini possible and god forbid make sure you are not over weight 4.  Never ever smile or say hello 5.  Never look like you are enjoying yourself because you are to cool to enjoy yourself 6.  Don't forget to do your yoga on the beach in your teeny tiny bikini in the morning How exhausting it must be so if you don't have these qualifications dont go to Hiriketiya stick to Dickwella beach.

This beach is known to be a recently developed destination in Sri Lanka. The tourist area is concentrated around lovely beach of a small bay that is surrounded by a green thicket. The area is full of budget accommodation, restaurants facing the beach and a range of water sports. The water sports equipment are available to hire at reasonable costs. Local community is extremely hospitable towards the tourists. I must visit if you love serene beaches.

If you‚Äôre reading this then you are about 2 years too late to visit what used to be Sri Lankas most beautiful beach. What was once a postcard is now covered with foam board rental shops and bob marley playing tiki bars, with rubbish strewn everywhere, plastic bottles and straws lapping in the water, and beginner surfers dropping in on anybody catching a wave. Go at sunrise to catch a glimpse at what once was, get your instagram shot, and be gone elsewhere after 5 minutes before it‚Äôs descended on by the mob.

Best is to go early morning around 6:30am or at 5pm to avoid the harsh sun and the crowd. The sea is very calm and you can swim in it. There are no corals so does not make sense trying to snorkel. The sea has small waves so its ideal for those who want to learn how to surf since the sea is not rough. There are many shops by the beach renting out surf boards for Rs. 500/- per hour and giving instructor lessons for Rs. 3,000/- per lesson. They also rent out sun lounge chairs for Rs. 300/- per hour and there are many shops that sell drinks, food and alcohol. There are many restaurants nearby where you can have lunch and dinner from and the rates per person are between Rs. 500/- to Rs. 2,000/- depending on what you order and where you eat from. What I hated was that it was overcrowded with too many surfers during the day time and local vendors trying to force foreigners to buy things and not giving you privacy.

Five of us, three adults and two kids stayed in a hotel from 22nd to 25th December 2019, close to the Hiriketya Beach with its lovely turquoise waters. The beach is in an oval shaped cove or a bay, sheltered on either side with two hillocks that protect the bay from strong winds.  The calm shallow waters invite you with its appealing and turquois blue. There is no current and the waves are gentle. There were many surfers too, some closer to the beach, others further away closer to bay entrance.  Surfing boards are available at Rs 500 per hour or Rs 1500 for the whole day.  Three of us had surfing lessons from one of the many available instructors and the cost was Rs 9000 for two hours.  Though surfing is available throughout the year, non-monsoonal months October to April are calm and preferable. All along this 500-metre-long beach are many cafes, restaurants and surfing board hires.  Beach chairs are dotted all along with many guests enjoying the sun and this marvellous little beach at a rustic village in a hidden corner of Sri Lanka. Expect the beach to be crowded and full of tourists, surfers and swimmers during the season November to March.

We had stopped en route from Yala to Matara for what we hoped would be a quick swim in a quiet cove... Instead, the area around the beach was disappointingly chaotic, clogged with traffic, and virtually inaccessible. The rapidly developing area adjacent is too cramped to accommodate all the surfers and Instagram tourists. The beach is small, over-crowded, and consequently uninviting. Even our overheated kids were discouraged and didn‚Äôt want to stay. A far cry from the ‚Äúmost beautiful beach in the world‚Äù we‚Äôd read about.

It's so sad to return to a beach that you visited 2 years previously (and that you still dream about) only to find that it's a totally different place. I stayed in the area for 4 days over Christmas and I was shocked at the state of this beach, and at the amount of people. Luckily I discovered Dikwella beach just next door for swimming in calmer waters and with it's beautiful sunsets. I went back to Tangalle, and also loved the beaches there, especially near Coconut Island. It doesn't seem to have changed at all in that area.
Great little beach but only problem there are soooo many people and soo many surfers. You can go to the back break to get away from the beginners
This is our second visit here. What a place! What a hidden gem!! Everything and more than what you want in a beach. Specially made for surfing!! Surfers boards, lessons, excellent food all available
We‚Äôre here for 6 days and it should be longer. Ocean is warm, surf is up, beach is stunning and it‚Äôs very relaxed and friendly. Not too many locals hustling.   Would highly recommend.

An amazing beach with many surfing schools around the bay. Breathtaking view of the blue water and the breaking of waves, blended with lush green surrounding. Plenty of Stay In lodges and hotels around at very reasonable rates.

This is the best place get surf lessons in hiriketiya. When you are go to the hiriketiya beach You can check and try to get surf lessons. They do amazing lessons. And also cool price. If you need book lessons from hiri surf school whatsapp or call:   +94769327173

A really pretty beach with good surf. Lots of restaurants and surf schools along the beach which are great if you want them but also contribute to the beach being a little crowded. Most deck chairs are free of charge as long as you buy a drink or some food at the bar that owns them - otherwise just lay on the sand. The food in the area was more westernised than other areas on Sri Lanka but also generally of a higher quality (apart from the rice and curry in other parts of the country).

We were on the hunt for the perfect beach in Sri Lanka. Hiriketiya was that for us; great for swimming or learning to surf. Unlike the other Sri Lankan beaches which are rocky with rough waves, this one is relatively calm and less deep.

My gf and I got swept out quite quickly to the edge of the bay on our visit. It is worth making sure that your read or at least learn about rip tides when visiting this beach. On our visit we were saved and hulled back to shore by 4 surfers! It was scary - - would be understating what it felt like! I would advice that if swimming there stay close to the shore, at least where you can stand. There are some great videos on YouTube on rip tides please review before swimming here.

If you‚Äôre anywhere near Hiriketiya on the south coast you HAVE to go to this beach. Our favourite beach in all of Sri Lanka. I think it helped that it was very quiet the day we went but it‚Äôs a beautiful beach with good waves for surfing.
Surfers are drawn to Hiriketiya Beach like a magnet. Rolling surf with stunning views. Plenty of places to stay of various costs.
This is a beautiful patch of beach here. The beach is a lovely area to  spend time,or go for a nice walk.

Due to unplanned development, the beach is eroding quickly and losing its charm. Garbage is becoming an issue. A few good spots to eat and chill (Dots, grove, salt house) but the surfing is tired and done. With all the local surf schools in the area congregating in this tiny bay there is no longer room to roam.  Best of all there‚Äôs an out of touch territorial local-expat scene taking shape. Lots of ‚Äòtoo-cool-for-school‚Äô hipster attitude in the water. This place was pure magic a couple years ago, sadly that day is no longer.

Nice waves when we visited (July 20th) for 3 days.  Waves were choppy, so not ideal for surfing (although several surfers were in the water). Super clear and clean turquoise water.  It was also possible to swim. Some restaurants were opened having prices 5 to 8 times the value of a normal restaurant in Sri Lanka.  Still a nice place to cool down after several weeks on the road.
Cool little beach.  Good food options but they are all tourist prices, no local restaurants.  The water can get very packed but the waves are worth it.  Watch out for the rocks scattered about

We had just arrived to the Beach and rented a surfboard for the hour to make the most of the late afternoon. Having a great and pleasant time until my husband hands back the board and then a young lad tries calling us over and demand 20,000rupees because of a crack in the board (all boards heavily used and not in new condition clearly as such a busy beach) Obviously argued that we would not pay such an obscene figure and that all the boards in used condition and we honestly did not cause any damage. Owner then follows my husband to our beach table and harassed us some more. Trying to diffuse the situation my husband again tried to say we are not paying and the owner grabbed his shirt and tried to drag him behind the shop but he managed to shout and push himself away. Owner then comes down to itimidate me alone on the beach in front of everyone. This surf stall is towards the west end of the beach with a simple black and white sign. Absolutely appalled by this behaviour - we are on our honeymoon and has left a bad impression of Sri Lanka. We returned to this country as we had visited before and know it had become very popular with tourists but we have never experienced such crookedness from the Sri Lankan people. Tourists are unfortunately being taken advantage of in these popular places and totally shocked at the intimidation and aggression. This beach is very busy - there is a lot of coastline to see so I do not recommend it as anything particularly special other then handy if you want to learn to surf but it is crowded. You will be targeted especially if you look vulnerable or like you have never surfed before (that‚Äôs clearly what happened to us). We are honest people and never normally leave a review but do feel people have to be wary of this place and this behaviour which we would have expected elsewhere but not in Sri Lanka. What a shame the locals are acting like this.

We rented 2 surfboards from the surfshop. They didn't make you sign anything which I thought was pretty carefree. The boards were in ok shape, a bit damaged. However, when we went to return them they said we had cause a small scratch on one of the boards (which we had not). They wanted 70$ from us to "fix" it. When I said there was no way we were paying that and to call the police, they refused and wouldn't let us leave. They called several other guys and said if we didn't pay them then we really would have to call the police, essentially threatening us with violence. We ended up giving them 30$ and they snickered as we left. DO NOT RENT A SURF HERE. Or if you do, make sure to take pictures of the board. The beach itself is alright. Nothing special, ok waves for beginners although on the day we were there they were not very frequent. Also, it is way too crowded since it is on the smaller side.

This beautiful patch of beach is wonderful, and really great for surfers. It has crystal blue waters, tiny fish, good waves and plenty of places with surf boards to rent. There are lots of beach bars and cafes too. The drawback? It's nowhere near as idyllic as other beaches around Sri Lanka as it's just full of white tourists, and so the businesses are tailored to thAt, the food is very western and so are the prices. There are some other amazing beaches nearby with very few people on, if any, and that is much more preferable to us!

Hiriketiya is a hidden beach reachable by taking a right turn @ Dodampahala junction beyond Dickwella town on Tangalle/Hambantota Mahawela) road. Within a few hundred meters you have to turn right right again on to a bad quality road (April 2019) leading up to the beach. Just follow Google Maps if you don't want to find the way on your own. I cannot find the right words to describe the graciousness of the place. It's an exceptional gradient of colors in the waters that attracted me first. It's simply magical. Breaking of waxes creates miriads of different patterns in the water that pleases the eye even more. Surfers from different parts of the world gather here practice their hobby. This beach is, in fact, a small bay guarded by a rocky mouth. And the beach is well shaded making it really cool even during hot days. There are a number of guest houses offering good quality accomodation and meals. For visitors who are not staying vehicle parking is an issue at the moment. However, situation can be expected to improve in the near future. Local authorities should pay more attention to this beach that is gaining recent popularity. The land value here is sky rocketing. There is a yellow minibus permanently parked by the beach, and is converted to a restaurant. Make sure that you visit this pristine beach when you travel this part of the island, even if you are not a surfer. But, please do not pollute the the surroundings of this amazing world.

We left our bag with the surf school just in front and to the left of the roti place as soon as you arrive to the beach. The same place we rented boards from. We came out the water and found one of the surf instructors going through our bag and stealing money. He was caught red handed. This obviously wasn‚Äôt the first time he had done it, by the reaction of the other guys working there. He didn‚Äôt take all the money just a couple thousand rupees, enough that we might not have noticed if we didn‚Äôt catch him actually with his hands in our bag taking it.

This beach is certainly beautiful, no doubt about that. The drawbacks are that it's narrow and steeply sloped, so there's only so much room to put your towel. Very little shade available without renting a sun bed. One end is good for swimming and suitable for small children (with caution). Several food sellers, with the usual sea-side markup on food and drinks. Being a non surfer I was still able to enjoy myself, as the views are very nice, but felt like grandpa the old man amidst all of the "kids".

A stunning little cove like bay lined with palm trees - what more could you want? Well, less people. Due to the nature of the beach you do feel as though if you roll over on your towel, you may end up squashing the person next to you... If peace and quiet are your thing, avoid. However, if crystal clear water and the utmost feeling of a tropical beach are, then this is the place to be for an afternoon.

The beach is ok not better than many others in  Sri Lanka, way too far from being the best one in the south coast. It is packed with chairs up to the water line and surfers + hipsters. The narrow stretch of coarse sand (and stones) can't handle the ammount of people. The only reason to come here is for the good waves to surf or watching good surfers on the left (East) side. Anyway this place need traffic lights in the ocean too :(. A few overpriced options to eat nearby. There are much better places to go in Sri lanka if you need to enjoy a nice beach with an authentic local mood. Maybe it is just a matter of taste, It is simply not for me, and for many others as I can see.

Our driver stopped to show us this beach on our way from Mirissa to Tissa. I wish I had known it existed! It is a little slice of heaven, a small bay with perfect surf. A couple of foreigner run cafes in the area reminded me of Byron Bay, Tulum, Seminyak... very cool vibes.

This is the only beach so far where there has not been any available seats at any of the beach side restaurants. The beach is really small and cozy. Good for surfing beginners and apparently also for families with kids. Supposedly this beach was a lovely hidden gem just a few years ago but the tourists have unfortunately come to stay.

Pretty cove. A few bars. 1 restaurant. We think we did perfect combo came at 4pm had drinks and chilled then quick early dinner. Not loads here. Sure if you are a surfer very cool we enjoyed watching those braver than us. Few toddlers seemed content. Lots of young nimble bodies! Felt very old at 36 ü§£ Worth a short trip for sure üå¥

We came to this beach thinking we would stay for 3 nights but had to leave the next morning, this beach is just a tourist trap, everything is made for tourists so the prices are higher than anywhere else we have been in Sri Lanka. There is no Sri Lankan culture , just a nice beach made to look like paradise for the vacationers. Its is away from the towns so they have all made the prices about the same and high and you dont really have a choice but to just keep spending your money. I honestly just felt like a dollar sign walking around and couldn't get out quicker. I didn't feel like anything was genuine. And then of course to get out of there you have to take a tuktuk that is 5 times the normal price. Quite disappointed.

This beach is magic, clear waters, calm near  the shore with a little surf break further out. Just gorgeous. We stayed about 15km away on Goyambokka beach, where accomodation was more suited to our family as Hiriketiya is oriented towards backpackers. But Hiriketiya beach is a must visit, we spent the day there, boys hired a board from a beach vendor (very cheap) and surfed for a few hours, we had lunch and drinks on the beach. It wasnt too busy when we were there in October.

we were lucky to discover this lovely beach and the bay which had high waves and was happy to see the surfers enjoying the waves. another corner was with some group enjoying sea bathing  and could see the fishers boats on the beach  and can imagine the friendly atmosphere with the hospitable Sri Lankans creating an inviting  atmosphere for the foreign and local visitors.

Quieter than some of the other areas, lovely beach, sheltered bay. Still enough waves to have some fun. Many children playing in the surf.  Small beach restaurants along the beach. Glad we came. We were there during off season, but the beach was calmer enough to swim.  Definitely worth a visit.
If there is a worldwide competition to find the prettiest beach in the world this one would have to come in the top 10.

We found this on our way to Tangalle, passing Dikwella. The access road to the beach is not the best but the trouble is all worth because it's one of the beautiful beaches with turquoise blue sea in SL and a great surf spot. Also the best thing about it is it's less crowded (you will find mostly foreigners) and clean. So i would call it a gem. Ideal spot for a good swim, sun bathing and to Surf. There are plenty of people who will hire surf boards and some will teach you too. Waves are ideal for both swim and surf. Make sure you take towels with you if you plan to visit because it's so tempting for a swim here. This is by far one of my favourite beaches and bathing spots in SL.

Had a great time with another family staying in a villa near the beach. We were sightly worried about going in August but had very nice weather the entire week, with the occasional rain and windy conditions.

We were blown away by Hiriketiya Beach - it‚Äôs so gorgeous! It is what I would describe as paradise! Lovely sand and clean, crystal waters. There is very good surf too for surfers! There are tasteful and well-run bars and restaurants/guest houses on the beach front too! Lots of memories of delicious food and beer right on the beach! I will be recommending this beach to everyone - the best we have been to in Sri Lanka!!

I really liked this beach a lot! Nice cove that was great for surfing. There was a right and left point break in either side of the cove. Also, good waves for beginners in from the points. Plenty of board rentals. Good for swimming too. This place will be big soon

We spent 3 days here in February and loved it so much we came back for another 2 days. This was our favourite beach we visited by far! We spent time in Bentota, Unawatuna, Delawella, Wijaya, Mirissa and Tangalle, but Hiriketiya was our favourite!! The beach was calm, the weather beautiful and although busy, we never struggled to get ourselves a lounge by the water. There are a number of food options including great local food on the beach or Western-style dishes back on Hiriketiya Road. It is walking distance or a short, cheap tuk-tuk ride from Dickwella town which is easily accessible by local bus. There are a number of reasonably priced guesthouse options in Hiriketiya right by the beach, or more expensive yoga retreat-style accommodation options for those with higher budgets. Hiriketiya is an extremely family-friendly location with a calm, sheltered beach; but even as a young childless couple we loved our time here!! Would highly recommend! Pure Paradise!

Clean water, safe beach, great restaurants. I find it hilarious that other people rate it poorly because it‚Äôs over crowded. It is one of the best beaches one can visit- of course it‚Äôs over crowded! Beach was busy (so was the sea) but it had a great vibe and everyone was very happy to be in paradise. Loads of good surf for beginners. Don‚Äôt miss it.

We stopped here for a few hours and secured a couple of seats in one of the restaurants/bars along the beach. The water was clean and clear with some small waves ideal for those wanting to learn to surf.

An amazing horseshoe bay, with a great vibe and manageable waves for beginners. A couple of bars provide cheap drinks and food along the beach. Surfboard hire is available with good condition boards available for very cheap (250rupee 1 hour, 1000 rupee all day). Highly recommended.

Wonderful beach , ( great woodfire pizza on the beach ) 3 place to rent surfboards and 3 placks to est , wonderful small bay.  A few nice Hotels and good restaurants , Jasper House we stayed at, great place

This hidden gem is well worth the trip wherever in Sri Lanka you're staying. It's a paradise lagoon with both a nice slow longboard wave consistently pumping as well as a faster left on a reef so there is surfing for everyone regardless of level. Three beach restaurants serves you both breakfast, lunch and dinner and one of them also offers massage. We arrived 06.30 am and wasn't able to leave until 6 pm thanks to this truly paradise place.

Wow! You need to go here! It's the most beautiful beach I've been to along the South coast! A perfect horse shoe bay with blue water and decent surf. There is a pretty shallow reef break to the left, but the wave is mellow so don't worry about it. And there is a good beginner surf spot right in front of the beach, beautiful clean waves with turtles frequently popping up next to you üòç The beach is super tranquil and just lovely! Not much budget food on the beach front, but we took a walk to the little town where it was more "backpack-priced"

Beautiful little beach with a groovy vibe. A couple of nice places to eat, coffee or a fresh drink. We had wood fired pizza which was very good. The water was very clean and it was a post card setting. Nice clean sand, coconut palms and some surfers further out. Waves were a but rough but it was great fun even with small children. (7 and 10 good swimmers). Not recommended if you want a calm place to swim. This beach is really as beautiful as it gets.

We only came here as out TukTuk driver convinced us to try it instead of Goyambokka. We were so glad he did! The beach itself is beautiful and there are a few bars and restaurants but not so many that the whole of the beach is overrun. The water was calm enough to swim in but was still popular with surfers. Give it a try!

Commonly referred to as "secret beach", Hiriketiya (or Hiri as I like to call it) is becoming less and less secret; however, the charm of a picturesque bay nestled in the jungle is a secret worth sharing. My friends and I would travel to Hiri once or twice a month to snorkel with turtles, eat at Salt House (highly recommended breakfast burritos!), and surf for a few hours at either the beach break or the more challenging point break. It's actually the perfect spot to spend an entire day. Kids can be occupied, couples can enjoy quiet space, and groups of friends can run wild. If you're travelling around the Island, make Hiriketiya a must-see on the itinerary.

We were at Hiriketiya Beach to surf and at first had a great time. We rented some surfboards at the place on the left side of the beach (if you look out into the ocean). After 10 minutes a rubber safety cord of a board ripped unsurprisingly, because they are simply, really old. When we brought it back they demanded us to pay 20$ for the cord of a 50$ surfboard. When I objected the owner tried to fight me and one of his buddies tried to explain to me, that we are all human and maybe I should just give the guy money, since he doesn't have much. Don't get boards from that place, since they're going to try to pick your pockets.

Wonderfull place and wonderfull beach for swimming.... The cafe/restaurants was a little expensive but nice anyway and really good lunch on the place that looks much like a coffee bar with lounge music.. a little in the back fro the beach... :)
Nice beach, perfect for surfers (beginners to good surfers). 3 nice restaurants on site where you can eat from srilankan food to pizzas and burgers. We loved it. It can be busy though

My boyfriend loves surfing and took me to this beach. It is one of the most beautiful beaches we have been to in Sri Lanka. Small beach with some lovely cafes with hammocks and shade, very relaxing and scenic. Many places to hire a good range of surfboards at a good price (250-500 rupees per hour depending on the board). Surfing suitable for experienced surfers at the point with some good waves, and also suitable for beginners with easy smaller waves in the bay. We loved this beach and came back the second day. There are a few options to stay here at guest house/hotel which we would do if we came back. We stayed at Tangalle which was about 20min drive away.

I was told that Hiriketiya beach was a stunning beach little known other than to a handful of surfers by a friend who had visited 3 years ago. It was indeed a stunning bay, however I would not quite agree with the secret part, as there were quite a few tourists lounging around on the beach. The adventure of finding the perfect deserted beach can wait when you have beauty like this!

A nice and relaxed bay, with the best curry we've had in 3 weeks holiday in Sri Lanka (on which we ate curry every day). We spent a small week in Hiriketiya with our 2 year old son. Hiriketiya is a bay that is predominantly focused on tourism. The small town Dikwella is separated from it (nice local market on Saturdays!). So you're dependent of the restaurants on the beach (4 in total). The beach house (owned by a western guy) is busiest for lunch (has an explicit lunch menu and a western orientation). But for diner one must go to SEA BREEZE. By far the best restaurant for diner on this small strip (we tried all). Chef Tensin is an absolute talent who works with whatever fresh stuff he could get his hands on that day. We ate there 3 times and every time the curries were totally different and absolutely delicious. Concerning the bay. Yes the waves are a bit less big in this bay than in most other places, however, they're still pretty big and there still is a big undertow. As a result one still needs to be an experienced swimmer and you can't just let your toddler play in the surf...

If you want to see how paradise can look like, go to this beach. –û—á–µ–Ω—å –∫—Ä–∞—Å–∏–≤–æ –∏ –ø—Ä–∏—è—Ç–Ω–æ! Sehr sehr sch√∂n und noch nicht √ºberf√ºllt. Sehr zu empfehlen! Very nice for surfing too!

Beautiful beach! Can almost guarantee in next few years tourism will take over so go now while it's still a somewhat secret paradise. Only thing I couldn't help but notice was the amount of NAKED children on the beach. Some of them 8 or 9 years old - in my option, very inappropriate. Protect your kids from the high UV and also cover them up!!

Wonderful quite beach which would be great for kids or if you are on a honeymoon. If you are looking to party maybe don't bother. I was here with two other mates and we just enjoyed the beach, had some fun small waves, and snokerlled and fished. Three places to eat. Dots beach house is good but really expensive. Hiriketiya beach house is nice. The other joint is shocking. Foods ok but takes at least an hour and a half to come out. We went three times. Twice for dinner and once for breaky. Go to either of the first two. It's a good place. Will prob get ruined by tourism over the next few years so go now!!
